facts.text: Assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 with previous years ended March 31, 1953 and March 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The matter relates to assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55, the companyresponding previous years for which ended on March 31, 1953 and March 31, 1954 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant-assessee is Managing Director of Messrs Hotels 1938 Ltd. and other associated companies controlling hotels in India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- assessee is the Managing Director of Messrs Hotels  1938  Ltd. and other associated companypanies companytrolling a number of hotels in India.

facts.text: For 1953-54, assessee showed Rs. 66,694 gross dividend from shares in Associated Hotels of India Ltd. (109,606 shares), Northern India Caterers Ltd. (20 shares), Oberoi Hotels Ltd. (10 shares).

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO for 1953-54 and 1954-55, referring to order dated November 24, 1959 for 1952-53.

facts.text: Income Tax Investigation Commission found assessee owned 78,650 shares own name, 15,885 wife Iswarani Debi, 6,823 son T.R. Oberoi, 5,000 daughter Rajarani Kapoor out of 200,000 ordinary shares as on 31-3-1947.

facts.text: Assessee's letter to Income Tax Investigation Commission: evaded income Rs. 20 lakhs invested mainly in shares of Associated Hotels of India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was also placed upon the following extract from a letter addressed by the assessee to the Commission In preparing the statement of wealth, I have taken into account all the assets of which I and other members of my family are possessed. According to the statement of wealth furnished the evaded income companyes to Rs. 20 lakhs.

facts.text: Income Tax Investigation Commission held shares acquired out of suppressed income of Rs. 16,62,211.

anchor.surface_text: It was also found that the Income Tax Investigation Commission had held that the shares had been acquired by the assessee out of the suppressed income which was determined to be Rs. 16,62,21 1.

facts.text: Income Tax Appellate Tribunal directed exclusion of Rs. 56,586 and Rs. 39,542 from assessee's income for 1953-54 and 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, the assessee companytended that the Income Tax Investigation Commission had companysidered only the shares of the Associated Hotels of India, but the bulk of dividend included in the assessees income in the two assessment years in question was the dividend declared by Northern India Catereres Ltd. ... The Tribunal accordingly directed that the income assessed for the assessee should be reduced by the amounts of Rs. 56,586 and Rs. 39,452

facts.text: High Court held shares purchased benami by assessee in name of wife and sons, assessee failed to discharge burden, real owner assessed on dividend despite registered holders.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ,in answering the question in the negative, observed that the shares in question had been purchased by the assessee in the name of his wife and two sons and, in the circumstances, the natural inference was that the purchases were benami transactions.

facts.text: Supreme Court found assessee admitted in past before department that shares belonged to him.

anchor.surface_text: In addition., to that, we find that the order of the Income Tax Officer for the assessment year 1953-54 shows that it had been admitted by the assessee in the past before the department that the shares in question standing in the name of the wife and two sons of the assessee belonged to him and were his own investments.

facts.text: No challenge in appeal to ITO's observation of past admission by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before us during the companyrse of arguments that numbersuch admission had been made, but numberhing was brought to our numberice to show that the above observation made by the Income Tax Officer had been challenged in appeal., No companyy of the memorandum of appeal filed against the order of the Income Tax Officer has been produced.

facts.text: Tribunal held observation of admission factually incorrect, no admission made.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal numberhere observed that the above observation was factually incorrect and that the said admission had number been made by the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court held ample material to infer assessee real owner, shares held benami.

anchor.surface_text: Although it is numbermally for the department to show that the apparent is number the real, in the present case we find that there was ample material to justify the inference that the assessee was the real owner of the shares and they were held by him benami in the name of his wife and two sons.

facts.text: Once found benami purchase, ownership presumed to continue unless shown otherwise; no such showing by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Once it was found that the assessee was the real owner of the shares and they had been purchased benami in the name of his wife and two sons, it would be presumed that the ownership of the shares companytinued to remain vested in the assessee,unless it was shown that because of some subsequent event, he had ceased to be the owner of the shares. No such attempt was made by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Once it was found that the assessee was the real owner of the shares and they had been purchased benami in the name of his wife and two sons, it would be presumed that the ownership of the shares continued to remain vested in the assessee,unless it was shown that because of some subsequent event, he had ceased to be the owner of the shares.

anchor.surface_text: What was held in that case was that a person who purchases shares in a company under blank transfer and in whose name the shares have not been registered in the books of the company is not a shareholder in respect of such shares within the meaning of section 18 5  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 notwithstanding his equitable right to the dividend on such shares.

concepts.interpretation: Defines shareholder for dividend grossing up; limited to registered holder per Howrah Trading
concepts.unlisted_description: Shareholder meaning for tax on dividends

anchor.surface_text: It was further held that such a person was not entitled to have his dividend income grossed up under section 16 2  of the Act by the addition of the income tax paid by the company in respect of those shares.

concepts.interpretation: Grossing up of dividend income applies to registered shareholders per Howrah Trading

anchor.surface_text: But the shares may because of a trust or other fiduciary relationship, belong to a person other than the registered shareholder, and the dividend distributed by the company would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or arise to the real owner of the shares.

concepts.interpretation: Dividend taxed to real owner despite company paying registered holder; per Kishanchand case
concepts.unlisted_label: Taxation to Real Owner of Shares
concepts.unlisted_description: Income from benami shares taxed to beneficial owner

anchor.surface_text: We may also observe that if the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal records a finding on the point as to whether a purchase was made benami or not, such a finding as observed in Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income Tax 1  would be considered to be one of fact.

concepts.unlisted_description: Tribunal finding on benami treated as factual

anchor.surface_text: If such finding is based upon some evidence, the same would have to be accepted in proceedings in a reference under section 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act.

concepts.interpretation: Limits High Court interference with factual findings in references

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was justified in excluding from the assessable income of the assessee for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the sums of Rs. 56,586 and Rs. 39,542 which were the amounts of dividend received by the assessee's wife and two sons from shares acquired out of the profits of the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was justified in excluding from the assessable income of the assessee for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the sums of Rs. 56,586 and Rs. 39,542 which were the amounts of dividend received by the assessee's wife and two sons from shares acquired out of the

issues.text: Whether the shares in question had been purchased by the assessee benami in the name of his wife and two sons and whether the assessee was the real owner thereof?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ,in answering the question in the negative, observed that the shares in question had been purchased by the assessee in the name of his wife and two sons and, in the circumstances, the natural inference was that the purchases were benami transactions.

issues.text: Whether the dividend income from the shares could be assessed in the hands of the assessee as the real owner even though the shares were registered in the names of his wife and sons?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the real owner could be assessed on the dividend income even though his wife and sons were the registered holders of the shares.

issues.text: Whether once benami purchase is found, the ownership of the shares is presumed to continue in the assessee unless a subsequent event is shown?

anchor.surface_text: Once it was found that the assessee was the real owner of the shares and they had been purchased benami in the name of his wife and two sons, it would be presumed that the ownership of the shares continued to remain vested in the assessee,unless it was shown that because of some subsequent event, he had ceased to be the owner of the shares.

issues.text: Whether a finding by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal on whether a purchase was made benami is a finding of fact binding in a reference under section 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 if based on evidence?

anchor.surface_text: We may also observe that if the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal records a finding on the point as to whether a purchase was made benami or not, such a finding as observed in Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income Tax 1  would be considered to be one of fact.

precedents.citation: Howrah Trading Co. v. Commissioner of Income Tax 1

anchor.surface_text: Howrah Trading Co. v. Commissioner of Income Tax 1 . What was held in that case was that a person who purchases shares in a companypany under blank transfer and in whose name the shares have number been registered in the books of the companypany is number a shareholder in respect of such shares within the meaning of section 18 5  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 numberwithstanding his equitable right to the dividend on such shares.

precedents.case_name: Howrah Trading Co. v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: a person who purchases shares in a company under blank transfer and in whose name the shares have not been registered in the books of the company is not a shareholder in respect of such shares within the meaning of section 18(5) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 notwithstanding his equitable right to the dividend on such shares; such a person was not entitled to have his dividend income grossed up under section 16(2) of the Act
precedents.cited_holding: registered holder under blank transfer not entitled to gross up dividend

precedents.citation: Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj Commissioner of Income Tax 2

anchor.surface_text: Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj Commissioner of Income Tax 2 . It was held in that case that a companypany for its purpose does number recognise any trust or equitable ownership in shares. It merely recognizes the registered shareholder as the owner and pays dividend to that shareholder. But the shares may because of a trust or other fiduciary relationship, belong to a person other than the registered shareholder, and the dividend distributed by the companypany would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or arise to the real owner of the shares.

precedents.case_name: Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: a company does not recognise any trust or equitable ownership in shares but recognizes only the registered shareholder; however, dividend can be taxed as accruing to the real owner due to trust or fiduciary relationship; grossing up scheme does not limit income to registered shareholder
